div.p: The Early Ruskin Manuscripts is an archive of the youthful writing of John Ruskin (1819–1900). Among the most multifaceted thinkers of the nineteenth century, Ruskin developed an approach to art criticism that probed the social, religious, political, and economic implications of appreciating beauty in the arts and the natural world. ERM contains the records of his education leading to that career, a body of work distinguished not only by its extraordinary quality and precocity but also by its variety and scope. The archive therefore presents a resource for students of Ruskin's development and of early Victorian culture and education generally.

In scope, the archive ranges from poetry and fiction to critical essays on the arts; from travelogues and topographical poetry and prose to sermons and religious verse; from mineralogy and geology to mathematics. Starting in 1826, the archiveʼs earliest documents reveal the Ruskin familyʼs engagement with late-Enlightenment pedagogy for young children; extending to 1842, later documents open up the experiences of an early Victorian Oxonian and the professionalization of a rising author.

Once the task of organizing, annotating, and exhibiting this mass of material is well underway, the archive also aims to facilitate study of how Ruskin became seemingly the most proto-hypertextual of Victorian writers. Late in his career, Ruskin experimented with writing and publication that anticipate modes later made possible by digital platforms. Straining the publication resources of his day, he invented an unbounded and hypertextual, if perhaps not quite nonlinear, series of monthly letters called Fors Clavigera. It is a valuable question how far Ruskinʼs innovations were grounded, for example, in a social-network methods of education promoted by the Edgeworths, or in a Romantic-era alertness to the interrelation of arts and disciplines.

In such questions and in the ongoing digitization of Ruskinʼs works, ERM joins other digital editions such as the Ruskinʼs Venetian Notebooks, and The Elements of Drawing. ERM most directly complements the Lancaster University's Electronic Edition of Modern Painters I, in the sense that the present archive can be viewed as editing the works leading up to that 1843 work, which established Ruskinʼs reputation as a popular art critic.

ERM is not the first edition of Ruskinʼs early writing, but, when complete, it will be the most comprehensive. Approximately a third of its materials has never before been available in edited form, and a large portion of the remainder has been available only in the problematically edited form of late-nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century editions. The archive also encourages awareness of the editorial, scholarly, and biographical tradition in which it stands, inviting critical assessment of a tradition of reflection on Ruskinʼs youth and education.

That tradition started in 1850, with the private publication of Poems by “J.R.,” collected by Ruskinʼs father, John James Ruskin, and by Ruskinʼs editor and his fatherʼs friend, W. H. Harrison. A contribution by Ruskin himself awaited his autobiographical reflections in the 1880s, when he proposed to print selected early poetry and prose as a “supplement” to his autobiography, Praeterita. This hypertextual link to the early writing was soon realized, however, by Ruskinʼs secretary, W. G. Collingwood, and his publisher, George Allen. They produced a series of editions of poetry and prose, starting with the 1891 Poems, which Collingwood edited with exemplary scholarship by the standards of the time. Transcripts of his edited versions of poems are included in the archive.

A complementary volume of early prose edited by Collingwood was planned but never executed. Instead, Allen was responsible for a small, somewhat haphazard miscellany of volumes of early prose writing, perhaps meant more to ply the heated trade for fine editions of fugitive writing by “modern writers” than to serve scholarship. These editions along with the 1891 Poems were absorbed into and editorially expanded in the first two volumes of the 1903–12 Library Edition, edited by E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn.

Thus, the transmission of Ruskinʼs early writing at the turn of the twentieth century is bound up, on one hand, with Ruskinʼs construction of his youth in the autobiographical narratives of Fors Clavigera and Praeterita, and, on another hand, with the cultural context of fine book collecting centering on modern authors that flourished in the 1890s. ERM provides a means to study these later contexts of transmission of the early Ruskin, which helped to shape subsequent scholarship, as well as the contexts of the early writingʼs first creation. ERM also advances an early twentieth-century project initiated by Helen Gill Viljoen, who started her scholarship early enough to have met Collingwood and to have examined the Ruskin manuscripts remaining in situ at Brantwood, Ruskinʼs last house, across Coniston Water from the village of Coniston in Cumbria. Viljoen went on to track (and did her part to secure) the early manuscriptsʼ subsequent fortunes, as they made their way from the 1930–31 auctions and private sales, through the hands of collectors, to widely scattered depositories. Viljoenʼs papers, recording her extensive bibliographic sleuthing that built on Collingwoodʼs foundations, have formed an important resource for the present edition. The papers, now deposited at the Pierpont Morgan Library should be regarded as forming an impressive archive in their own right.

Viljoenʼs efforts were sustained throughout the second half of the twentieth century by Van Akin Burd and James Dearden, who continued to edit unpublished early manuscripts, correct errors in the Library Edition, and carry out other original bibliographical research, including a key edition for the present archive, Burdʼs Ruskin Family Letters (1973). Building on this tradition and (it is hoped) contributing new avenues of scholarship, ERM assembles digital facsimiles of the manuscripts along with transcripts encoded according to the standards of the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI), allowing for expansion in content and extensibility in markup unavailable to earlier editors. The edition is offered as an interdisciplinary research site for a new generation of Romantic and Victorian studies.
